description:
[Cola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cola) soft drink. You would use this word when ordering a Coke (but there's another word specifically for Pepsi).

**Ordering**

{杯} is *cup* (or mug or glass) and is the [measure word](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measure_word) for water (and other drinks), and {一} is *one*, so to order a glass of cola, ask for 一杯可樂 (yāt būi hó lohk in Cantonese, yī bēi kě lè in Mandarin), *one cup of water*.

**Characters**

{可樂} is a [loanword](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) for *cola* (the Mandarin pronunciation *kě lè* is pretty close), but in a punny way it also means *entertaining*.

images.place: Lucky House Cafe, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
[Cola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cola) soft drink with slices of lemon.

**Characters**

This word combines two [loanwords](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) -- {檸檬} is a [loanword](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) for *lemon*, and {可樂} is (and sounds like) *cola*.
{健} is *healthy*, {怡} is *pleasure*, and {健怡} is *cola*, so 健怡可樂 is *healthy pleasure cola*, which sounds more enticing than just *diet cola*.

images.place: Dim Sum Cafe, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
The Cantonese for [Pepsi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pepsi) is *baak sih*, which sort of sounds like *Pepsi*.

**Personal Note**

In Hong Kong, I would order Pepsi more often than Coke because I found the Cantonese for Coke, {可樂} (hó lohk) more difficult to say.
